questions.text: What surgery is done here?
questions.solution: • The picture clearly shows a long incision for harvesting the vein without any damage for CABG*

questions.text: The PDA is kept patent by administration of PGE1 at birth in which anomaly
questions.solution:
• Patients with TGA-IVS typically present in the early newborn period with profound cyanosis associated with normal perinatal PDA closure.
  • In the absence of a significant ASD, the cyanosis is severe and progresses to death if left untreated.

Reference: Sabiston 21st edition Page no: 1659

choices.text: U/L absence of pectoralis major muscle only
U/L absence of pectoralis major + minor both
U/L absence of pectoralis major + minor + aplasia of ribs
U/L absence of pectoralis major + minor + aplasia of ribs + absence of breast tissue

questions.text: Poland syndrome can be characterized by
questions.solution:
• Poland syndrome is a unilateral pectoral aplasia/dysdactylia syndrome characterized by unilateral absence of the costosternal portion of the pectoralis major muscle, absence of the pectoralis minor muscle, aplasia or deformity of the costal cartilages of the second through the fifth ribs, hypoplasia or absence of the breast and nipple, hypoplasia of the subcutaneous tissue of the region, alopecia of the axillary and mammary region, and brachy syndactyly, all on the same side.
  • Administration of intravenous PGE1 is almost uniformly successful in re-establishing ductal patency to improve the patient’s arterial saturation by providing left-to-right shunting and improved pulmonary blood

Sabiston 21st edition ,Page no: 1622

questions.text: Which of the following arrhythmia is characteristic of halothane

A 57-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents to the hospital with new orthopnea and edema. His blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 96 beats per minute. He has clear lungs, a displaced cardiac apex with a third heart sound but no cardiac murmurs, and no lower extremity edema. Laboratory test results were as follows: hemoglobin 14 g/dL, sodium 137 mEq/L, potassium 4.4 mEq/L, and serum creatinine 1.7 mg/dL. Chest radiography shows pulmonary congestion with cardiomegaly. The ECG shows sinus rhythm, nonspecific ST-T changes, and frequent premature ventricular complexes . Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 20% and a dilated left ventricle. What should be the next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution: The patient has dilated cardiomyopathy. The most common cause of dilated cardiomyopathy, especially in a person with atherosclerotic risk factors, is coronary artery disease. The most appropriate next step for this patient would be to perform coronary angiography, the best diagnostic test in this circumstance. Stress testing may have false-positive or false-negative results in patients with dilated cardio-myopathy. Endomyocardial biopsy should not be routinely performed in the evaluation of patients with heart failure. Holter monitoring is useful in detecting the PVC burden over a 24-hour period, and if the PVC burden were especially high, it could be implicated as a rare cause of heart failure. However, Holter minitoring would not be the next step in evaluation and should not be performed without initiating medical therapy because indicated medical treatment (eg, β-blockers) can attenuate PVCs. Sleep apnea could be a frequent accompaniment of decompensated heart failure, but a sleep study should be performed only after patients are optimally treated.

questions.text: Identify the device used for Left atrial appendage closure in patients with atrial fibrillation and may be useful in patients with recurrent cardioembolic stroke, not responding to anticoagulants ?
questions.solution: Watchman device is a parachute shaped device used for Left Atrial Appendage Closure in Atrial Fibrillation.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient with history of Trauma to the chest, presented with Hypotension, muffled heart sounds and raised JVP. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space in a quantity suf­ficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles results in cardiac tamponade.

The most common causes of tamponade are idiopathic pericarditis and pericarditis secondary to neoplastic disease, tuberculosis, or bleeding into the pericardial space after leakage from an aortic dissection, cardiac operation, trauma, and treatment with anticoagulants.

The three principal features of tamponade (Beck’s triad) are hypoten­sion, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent.

questions.text: The ECG below is diagnostic of ?
questions.solution: In Mobitz type 1 Heart block/ Wenckebech Phenomena, Gradually progressive PR interval prolongation occurs before the blocked sinus impulse, with the greatest PR increment typically occurring between the first and second beats of a cycle, gradually decreasing in subsequent beats. Shortening of the PR interval occurs after the blocked sinus impulse, provided that the P wave is conducted to the ventricle.

choices.text: There is no change in the click with squatting or standing.
A passive leg raise makes the click-murmur occur earlier.
A squat maneuver makes the click-murmur occur later.
The mitral regurgitant murmur does not change with positional maneuvers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to your office for evaluation. She appears healthy and is not limited by physical activity. She says that she has occasional chest pains that occur at rest, often with a change in position. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 76 beats per minute and regular. Auscultatory findings are a midsystolic click followed by a 2/6 apical systolic murmur that radiates to her axilla. Which of the following dynamic physical examination findings would confirm your suspicion of mitral valve prolapse?
questions.solution: This 30-year-old patient presents with atypical chest pain, which may be associated with mitral valve prolapse. Mitral valve prolapse is essentially a mismatch of the left ventricular cavity size and the mitral valve leaflets, which are redundant. The classic bedside maneuver is the squat-to-stand maneuver; however, any maneuver that increases the left ventricular cavity size will delay midsystolic clicks and the mitral regurgitant murmur (Figure 2.A8). The Valsalva maneuver decreases venous return, which would result in a smaller left ventricle and thus an earlier mitral valve pro-lapse. A post extrasystolic beat (due to the compensatory pause), the passive leg raise, and squat (all would improve left ventricular filling) should actually delay mid-systolic clicks and murmur

questions.text: The pulse tracing shown below is most likely that of a patient with :
questions.solution: Pulsus alternans (alternation of one strong and one weak beat without a change in the cycle length) occurs most commonly in left ventricular failure

questions.text: The given ECG trace is that of a patient admitted in ICU. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: The ECG finding of a positive deflection at the J point (negative in aVR and V1) with a dome or hump configuration is most frequently termed a J wave or Osborn wave. There is no definitive physiological cause for the deflection despite numerous postulates. Broad differential diagnosis of prominent Osborn waves including hypothermia; benign early repolarization; hypercalcaemia and the Brugada syndrome

questions.text: A 80 year old male patient presented with complaints of exertional dyspnoea, chest pain and syncope. On examination, pulse-86/ min regular, BP 160/90mmhg, apex impulse shifted laterally, paradoxical splitting of S2 and Mid-systolic murmur heard in right 2nd intercostals space. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Exertional dyspnea, angina pectoris, and syncope are the three cardinal symptoms of AS

On Examination,

The carotid arterial pulse rises slowly to a delayed peak (pulsus parvus et tardus). A thrill or anacrotic “shudder” may be palpable over the carotid arteries, more commonly the left.

The LV impulse is sometimes displaced laterally in the later stages of the disease.

The murmur of AS is characteristically an ejection (mid) systolic murmur that commences shortly after the S1, increases in intensity to reach a peak toward the middle of ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure. It is characteristically low-pitched, rough and rasping in character, and loudest at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space

questions.text: The following is the ECG of a patient done as a part of routine work up before a major surgery. Seeing the abnormality, a medicine consultation is done to comment on this ECG. What is the likely explanation the medicine consultant has for the ECG finding ?
questions.solution: The ECG finding is that of Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). LBBB may be a finding in ischemic heart disease, cardiomyopathy and hypertensive heart disease.

questions.text: The following is the ECG of a patient who presented with acute onset breathless to the emergency. What is the confirmatory test for the diagnosis of the patient ?
questions.solution:
The ECG is showing electrical alternans.
Electrical alternans, i.e. alternating QRS voltage, is a specific but insensitive ECG finding of a large pericardial effusion with tamponade. It is caused by mechanical anterior–posterior swinging of the heart in the large fluid. Echo will help to confirm the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Speckled appearance of myocardium in Echo is a feature of ?
questions.solution: “Speckled appearance” of myocardium in ECHO is a feature of cardiac amyloidosis. This is due to amyloid accumulation in the cardiac tissue.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man undergoes a heart valve replacement due to chronic valvular stenosis. His physician explains to him that his valve problem probably arose from repeated episodes of which childhood disease?
questions.solution: Chronic rheumatic heart disease, which results from repeat episodes of rheumatic fever, is a cause of chronic valvular stenosis. Rheumatic fever results from pharyngeal infection with certain strains of group A Streptococcus.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man, a South American immigrant, presents with biventricular heart failure with peripheral oedema, hepatosplenomegaly, and pulmonary congestion. Global heart enlargement is seen on chest radiography. Electrocardiography reveals right bundle-branch block and left anterior fascicular block. Serum collected from the patient and run on ELISA detects antibodies to an agent transmitted by the bite of reduviid bugs. What is the cause of this man's disease?
questions.solution: The case is descriptive of myocarditis in Chagas disease. T. cruzi is a flagellated protozoan parasite transmitted by reduviid bugs and endemic to areas of South and central America.

questions.text: Functional Closure of ductus arteriosus is completed by?
questions.solution:
The closure of DA begins functionally soon after birth but functional closure is completed by 10-15 hr of birth according to most standard textbooks. Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus occurs between Day 10 to Day 21 of life.

Also remember the following:

questions.text: A neonate developed cyanosis in the first week of life. The child was put on 100% O2 followed by IPPV but there was no improvement. He was started on alprostadil infusion intravenously, following which the cyanosis improved dramatically. All of the following conditions can produce such a clinical picture except?
questions.solution: Complex congenital heart diseases, where survival is improved by keeping the ductus arteriosus open, are called as Ductus Dependent Congenital Heart Diseases. All the 4 mentioned conditions are ductus dependent lesions. However, options B, C and D present with cyanosis since they are ductus dependent pulmonary circulatory lesions, while HLHS presents with shock and improves with Alprostadil since it is a ductus dependent systemic circulatory lesion in the neonates and hence will be the odd-one out as well as the answer in this question.

questions.text: All of the following conditions show pulmonary plethora except?
questions.solution: Conditions showing Pulmonary Plethora on CXR are those which produce overloading of pulmonary circulation. This includes Acyanotic L-R Shunt Lesions like ASD, VSD, PDA as well as Endocardial Cushion Defect. Among cyanotic diseases, TGA and TAPVC have cyanosis with increased Pulmonary blood flow hence they will also produce Pulmonary Plethora. Remember that TOF, Ebstein’s Anomaly and Tricuspid Atresia have reduced Pulmonary Blood Flow and thus will show Pulmonary Oligemia, instead of Pulmonary Plethora

Troponin levels remain elevated after an MI for 4 to 10 days.
Cardiac Troponin is the preferred diagnostic marker for an MI.
Cardiac Troponin is elevated only in MI and not other sources of heart muscle damage.

A 54 yr old complaints of palpitation, weakness and lightheadedness. His ECG reports is attached. Which of the following can be the pharmacological therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Second-degree AV block (Mobitz Type I) - AV conduction time progressively lengthens before a block.

Indications of permanent pacing:

  • Symptomatic brady with any degree of AV block
  • Asymptomatic brady with second-degree Mobitz type II
  • Asymptomatic brady with third-degree AV block.

Pharmacological treatment:

Intravenous atropine à 0.5 mg IV

A 45 yr old female on prescription of an anti-HT drug, gradually started to develop joint pain, muscle pain and fever. There was associated photosensitivity and skin changes as shown in figure. On investigation, ANA was positive. Which of the following drug would have caused this?
questions.solution: Drug induced SLE

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with mental obtundation. He is found to have a blood pressure of 220/160 and retinal hemorrhages. Which one of the following is used in severe hypertensive emergencies, is short acting, acts on a G protein-coupled receptor, and must be given by intravenous infusion?

According to Vaughan - Williams - Singh classification of anti-arrhythmic, Identify the segment of action potential most affected by Ibutilide from the following illustration (Marked in roman letters I,II,III and IV)
questions.solution: Ibutilide is a class III anti-arrhythmic agent. It blocks outward K+ channels during phase 3 of action potential. It affects duration of action potential without affecting phase 0 depolarization or resting membrane potential.

questions.text: A 65 yr old woman came with the complaints of B/L peripheral edema. On examination, jugular venous distension, ascites are present. A CT scan of the patient shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The Non-Contrast CT image demonstrates pericardial thickening with prominent calcification typical of constrictive pericarditis
  • Constrictive Pericarditis has thickening of pericardium > 4mm with pericardial calcifications in about 50% cases ,causes diastolic dysfunction and manifests features of Rt Heart Failure.
  • Pericardial stripping/resection of pericardium(pericardiectomy) is done for these patients

  • Radial Ray Anomalies can be associated with

  • TAR syndrome-Thrombocytopaenia and Absent Radius
  • Vacterl Anamolies

Holt Oram Syndrome-Autosomal Dominant Disorder with congenital heart disease and upper limb defects

questions.text: 70 year old male suffered stroke after recent MI,CECT Images given indicate
questions.solution:
Series of cect image at the level of cardiac apex show a nonenhancing

Rounded thrombus in the left ventricle.

Intraventricular thrombi especially LV thrombi are common after acute MI and present with embolic episodes stroke,limb ischemia

Intraatrial thrombi are common after Atrial fibrillation/mitral stenosis

Lack of Contrast enhancement helps differentiate thrombus from other cardiac tumors

Myxomas generally arise from interatrial septum projecting into left atrium

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is found, by arteriography, to have 50% narrowing of her left renal artery. What is the expected change in blood flow through the stenotic artery?
questions.solution: If the radius of the artery decreased by 50% (1/2), then resistance would increase by 24, or 16 (R = 8$l/(r4). Because blood flow is inversely proportional to resistance (Q = #P/R), flow will decrease to 1/16 of the original value

questions.text: When a person moves from a supine position to a standing position, which of the following compensatory changes occurs?
questions.solution: When a person moves to a standing position, blood pools in the leg veins, causing decreased venous return to the heart, decreased cardiac output, and decreased arterial pressure. The baroreceptors detect the decrease in arterial pressure, and the vasomotor center is activated to increase sympathetic outflow and decrease parasympathetic outflow. There is an increase in heart rate (resulting in a decreased PR interval), contractility, and total peripheral resistance (TPR). Because both heart rate and contractility are increased, cardiac output will increase toward normal

questions.text: At which site is systolic blood pressure the highest?
questions.solution: Pressures on the venous side of the circulation (e.g., central vein, right atrium, renal vein) are lower than pressures on the arterial side. Pressure in the pulmonary artery (and all pressures on the right side of the heart) are much lower than their counterparts on the left side of the heart. In the systemic circulation, systolic pressure is actually slightly higher in the downstream arteries (e.g., renal artery) than in the aorta because of the reflection of pressure waves at branch points

questions.text: A person's electrocardiogram (ECG) has no P wave, but has a normal QRS complex and a normal T wave. Therefore, his pacemaker is located in the
questions.solution: The absent P wave indicates that the atrium is not depolarizing and, therefore, the pacemaker cannot be in the sinoatrial (SA) node. Because the QRS and T waves are normal, depolarization and repolarization of the ventricle must be proceeding in the normal sequence. This situation can occur if the pacemaker is located in the atrioventricular (AV) node. If the pacemaker were located in the bundle of His or in the Purkinje system, the ventricles would activate in an abnormal sequence (depending on the exact location of the pacemaker) and the QRS wave would have an abnormal configuration. Ventricular muscle does not have pacemaker properties.

questions.text: If the ejection fraction increases, there will be a decrease in
questions.solution: An increase in ejection fraction means that a higher fraction of the enddiastolic volume is ejected in the stroke volume (e.g., because of the administration of a positive inotropic agent). When this situation occurs, the volume remaining in the ventricle after systole, the end-systolic volume, will be reduced. Cardiac output, pulse pressure, stroke volume, and systolic pressure will be increased

choices.text: increased cardiac output for a given enddiastolic volume
increased cardiac output for a given endsystolic volume
decreased cardiac output for a given end-diastolic volume
decreased cardiac output for a given end-systolic volume

questions.text: An increase in contractility is demonstrated on a Frank-Starling diagram by
questions.solution: An increase in contractility produces an increase in cardiac output for a given end-diastolic volume, or pressure. The Frank-Starling relationship demonstrates the matching of cardiac output (what leaves the heart) with venous return (what returns to the heart). An increase in contractility (positive inotropic effect) will shift the curve upward

choices.text: partial occlusion of a blood vessel

questions.text: The tendency for blood flow to be turbulent is increased by
questions.solution: Turbulent flow is predicted when the Reynolds number is increased. Factors that increase the Reynolds number and produce turbulent flow are decreased viscosity (hematocrit) and increased velocity. Partial occlusion of a blood vessel increases the Reynolds number (and turbulence) because the decrease in cross-sectional area results in increased blood velocity (v = Q/A)

choices.text: an exaggerated response of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
a suppressed response of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
an exaggerated response of the baroreceptor mechanism
a suppressed response of the baroreceptor mechanism

questions.text: A 66-year-old man, who has had a sympathectomy, experiences a greater than-normal fall in arterial pressure upon standing up. The explanation for this occurrence is
questions.solution: Orthostatic hypotension is a decrease in arterial pressure that occurs when a person moves from a supine to a standing position. A person with a normal baroreceptor mechanism responds to a decrease in arterial pressure through the vasomotor center by increasing sympathetic outflow and decreasing parasympathetic outflow. The sympathetic component helps to restore blood pressure by increasing heart rate, contractility, total peripheral resistance (TPR), and mean systemic pressure. In a patient who has undergone a sympathectomy, the sympathetic component of the baroreceptor mechanism is absent

questions.text: The ventricles are completely depolarized during which isoelectric portion of the electrocardiogram (ECG)?
questions.solution: The PR segment (part of the PR interval) and the ST segment are the only portions of the electrocardiogram (ECG) that are isoelectric. The PR interval includes the P wave (atrial depolarization) and the PR segment, which represents conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node; during this phase, the ventricles are not yet depolarized. The ST segment is the only isoelectric period when the entire ventricle is depolarized

questions.text: In which of the following situations is pulmonary blood flow greater than aortic blood flow?
questions.solution: a left-to-right ventricular shunt, a defect in the ventricular septum allows blood to flow from the left ventricle to the right ventricle instead of being ejected into the aorta. The “shunted” fraction of the left ventricular output is therefore added to the output of the right ventricle, making pulmonary blood flow (the cardiac output of the right ventricle) higher than systemic blood flow (the cardiac output of the left ventricle). In normal adults, the outputs of both ventricles are equal in the steady state. In the fetus, pulmonary blood flow is near zero. Right ventricular failure results in decreased pulmonary blood flow. Administration of a positive inotropic agent should have the same effect on contractility and cardiac output in both ventricles

choices.text: decreased firing rate of the pacemaker in the sinoatrial (SA) node
decreased firing rate of the pacemaker in the atrioventricular (AV) node
increased firing rate of the pacemaker in the SA node
decreased conduction through the AV node

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows two P waves preceding each QRS complex. The interpretation of this pattern is
questions.solution: A pattern of two P waves preceding each QRS complex indicates that only every other P wave is conducted through the atrioventricular (AV) node to the ventricle. Thus, conduction velocity through the AV node must be decreased

choices.text: Decreased firing rate of the carotid sinus nerve
Increased parasympathetic outflow to the heart

questions.text: An acute decrease in arterial blood pressure elicits which of the following compensatory changes?
questions.solution: A decrease in blood pressure causes decreased stretch of the carotid sinus baroreceptors and decreased firing of the carotid sinus nerve. In an attempt to restore blood pressure, the parasympathetic outflow to the heart is decreased and sympathetic outflow is increased. As a result, heart rate and contractility will be increased. Mean systemic pressure will increase because of increased sympathetic tone of the veins (and a shift of blood to the arteries

questions.text: The tendency for edema to occur will be increased by
questions.solution: Edema occurs when more fluid is filtered out of the capillaries than can be returned to the circulation by the lymphatics. Filtration is increased by changes that increase Pc or decrease (c. Arteriolar constriction would decrease Pc and decrease filtration. Dehydration would increase plasma protein concentration (by hemoconcentration) and thereby increase (c and decrease filtration. Increased venous pressure would increase Pc and filtration

A blood culture grows streptococcus, viridians group. His erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is increased. He recovers after treatment with antibiotics. Which of the following chemical meditators is most likely to opsonize the bacteria and participate in their clearance?
